He conducted experiments with pea plants, cross-breeding different traits such as tall and dwarf plants, green and yellow peas, and purple and white flowers. Mendel's work showed that each parent had a 'vote' in the appearance of the offspring, and the non-dominant trait appeared only when inherited from both parents. This concept of dominant and recessive traits was a major contribution to the understanding of heredity.

Mendel's experiments on cultivated varieties of plants were published in 1865 but did not gain much attention until thirty-five years later. His work with pea plants demonstrated the separate inheritance of traits and the ratio of dominant to recessive traits in offspring. This associateal knowledge laid the groundwork for the understanding of genetic inheritance and the development of modern genetics.

In addition to his associateal work in genetics, Mendel's experiments unintentionally solved a major problem with Charles Darwin's theory of evolution, regarding how new traits were preserved and not blended back into the population. Mendel's work was not rediscovered until about 1900, but it had a significant impact on the understanding of genetics and evolution.

Overall, Gregor Mendel's experiments with pea plants and his observations of hereditary traits laid the associate for modern genetics and had a profound impact on the understanding of genetic inheritance and evolution. His work continues to be studied and revered in the field of genetics and biology.
